awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: Urban Tech Academy meeting on electrified multimodal transportation
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal funding will support travel grants for graduate students from US universities to attend the Urban Tech Academy & Summit, taking place from November 13th to 15th, 2023, at the Cornell Tech campus in New York City. The summit aims to address urban issues through technology and engineering ventures, with a specific focus on "sustainable cities" this year.
In the new format for the meeting, one day will be added to the program (called the Urban Tech Academy Day) to expand its educational outreach and scope. The Urban Tech Academy Day will include talks and discussions on emerging problems that the research community needs to address from leading experts. The specific Intellectual Merit of the discussion will be on multi-modal transportation and its electrification, critical for sustainable cities. Current research fails to holistically address the coupling between various transportation modes and their dependence on electric power infrastructure. Researchers will discuss how cyber-physical system models can help optimize and operate these heterogeneous charging systems effectively in different urban environments, promoting resilience, fairness, efficiency, and rapid decarbonization.

The Broader Impacts section emphasizes the significance of solutions to urban challenges, including housing costs, decarbonization, climate change, and resource distribution. The Urban Tech Academy Day's synergy with the summit is expected to broaden its impact. While the NSF funding primarily supports student participation, the involvement of top researchers in the electrified multi-modal transportation field and the co-occurrence of the two meetings will naturally attract industry stakeholders, startups, and institutional players in New York City.
The goal is to foster innovation, engage various stakeholders, and provide solutions for pressing urban challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The National Science Foundation (NSF) co-sponsored the 2023 Urban Tech Academy & Summit, held from November 13th to 15th, 2023, at Cornell Tech in New York City. The summit, titled *"Cities: The Ultimate Decarbonization Technology,"* focused on sustainable urban development through innovative technologies. The event brought together academics, industry leaders, government officials, and students to discuss decarbonization, electrification, and the transformation of urban infrastructure. The Urban Tech Academy, held on the first day, provided a deep dive into the technical challenges and opportunities presented by decarbonizing energy and mobility systems. Students, supported by NSF funding, attended sessions that covered cutting-edge research on optimizing electrified multimodal transportation, grid integration, and energy management strategies. The co-organizers were

1. Mahnoosh Alizadeh - UC Santa Barbara

2. Abhishek Dubey - Vanderbilt University

3. Anna Scaglione - Cornell University

The conference site is  https://www.urbantechsummit.com/urban-tech-academy

Key activities

1. Technical Sessions:

   - The morning session, titled "Optimizing Electrified Multimodal Transportation," addressed algorithms and strategies to minimize charging costs and optimize transportation systems. This session included the following speakers:

1. Scott Moura - UC Berkeley

2. Andrea Lodi - Jacobs Institute at Cornell Tech

3. Aron Laszka - College of Information Sciences and Technology at Pennsylvania State University

4. Varun Adibhatla - NYC School Bus Umbrella Services, Inc.

5. Walter Guo - Assistant Professor at the University of Central Florida

6. Junjie Qin - Assistant Professor at Purdue University

7. Lang Tong - Professor of Engineering at Cornell University

   - The afternoon session, focused on "Grid Integration of Electrified Transportation Services," explored the impact of electrification on the electric grid. Topics covered included grid stability, the interaction between electric vehicles and grid infrastructure, and energy management strategies. The speakers were:

1. Ziqi Song - University at Buffalo

2. Anurag Srivastava - Lane Professor and Chairperson of Computer Science and Electrical Engineering at West Virginia University

3. Rob Ewashchuk - Lyft

4. Venu Garikapati - National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL)

5. Saar Golde - Via Transportation

About 100 students from various universities in the area participated to the event, as well as faculty. The students' registratgion was sponsored with NSF funds, in addition to few students that had to travel, whose travel expenses were also covered with NSF fundign. 

 

2. Collaborative Research and Networking Opportunities

   - Participants from academia, industry, and government engaged in discussions about new technical ideas and research directions, aimed at promoting multimodal transportation solutions that address climate change, equity, health, and safety. The Academy provided an opportunity for students to engage directly with researchers and professionals, facilitating networking and collaboration on future projects.

 

Overall the feedback was very positive both from scholar and industry participants and from students, who had also the opportunities of connecting with other peers in colleges in the tri-state area that are interested in themes at the nexus of energy and transportation systems. 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2024
Modified by: Anna Scaglione
